sections: Editor’s note: Here are the weekend must-reads, and after that is Sirota’s weekly note to subscribers.
Stuff The Daily Poster reported this week:
We Are Guaranteed Only One Thing, Nothing More
How The Lincoln Project Set Liberals’ Money On Fire
The ACA Is Becoming A Political Problem For Dems
America’s Panic Attack Could Soon Be Over — But It’s Just The Beginning
We Can’t Follow Obama Back to Brunch
Emails Show Trump's CDC went MIA in Pennsylvania
Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez on Biden’s Win, House Losses, and What’s Next for the Left
A must-read Q&A with Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez. Just read the whole thing. She is awesome.
Working People Delivered Biden His Victory

Fantastic piece from Bernie 2020 co-chair Nina Turner, who writes that “it was working people’s organizations that had millions of conversations with voters this year. It was not the political operatives at the Lincoln Project or the Third Way who knocked the doors, who spoke to the voters, who heard their concerns.”
We Were Told Biden Was The 'Safe Choice'. But It Was Risky To Offer So Little

Naomi Klein writes: “After days of gnawing our fingers down to the quick, it’s fair to say that Biden was not safe at all, as we always knew. Not safe for the planet, not safe for the people on the front lines of police violence, not safe for the millions upon millions of people who are seeking asylum, but also not even safe as a candidate.”
Biden Wins, But Now The Hard Part Begins
The battle for the soul of the Democratic Party is once again raging.
America’s Next Authoritarian Will Be Much More Competent
If you are a regular Daily Poster reader, you know I’ve been saying this exact thing for months.
The Solution To Trump-Biden Polarization May Be Easier (And Cheaper) Than We Think

(NBC News) — I don’t agree with everything in this article, but there is a core truth: donating to honest, hard-hitting journalism is a lot smarter and more constructive than continuing to just donate to political candidates every few years.
San Francisco Voters Approve First-In-The-Nation CEO Tax That Targets Income Gap
(Cal Matters) — A big win for economic justice in the heart of economic inequality.
I was on All Things Considered to discuss the 2020 election, and how Democrats had big problems because they did not have a clear economic message.
Great discussion with journalist Owen Jones and climate reporter Kate Aronoff about what the election means for the left.

This past week was a long year. I don’t know about you, but I’m mentally exhausted from it all. Yes, I am relieved that Trump is on his way out, but mostly I feel overwhelmed and tired — and the worst part is, we all know that money never sleeps, so if we take a rest, then nothing will fundamentally change. Indeed, these next few weeks and months could determine the next few years.

There is little doubt that we are in for a rough winter — the pandemic will likely get worse, Trump will probably try to do damage on his way out of office and we’re all suffering from a form of mass PTSD from the year we’ve experienced. But I still remain optimistic that 2020 could be a year that catalyzes positive change.

Think about it; even as we’ve been quarantined and socially isolated, this has been a year of collective experience like few others. In many years, we are going through our own lives, doing our own thing. But this year, we’ve all gone through a pandemic, a national election and a climate crisis that has touched every corner of the country.

Every person in America has been touched by these things — and so while we may feel particularly polarized and divided, I think there’s a chance that these collective experiences have reminded us that we are all in this together.

Maybe that’s me being overly optimistic or unrealistic, because sure, there is an entire media misinformation machine designed to continue ripping us apart and isolating us in our own news bubbles. But I think the experiences have been so powerful and formative that they will have a lasting effect — and I think we may look back on this year as a time when we realized that our lives are all intertwined, whether we like it or not.
Back in 2008, I published a book called

— which was about how politics was becoming a competition between progressives and conservatives to try to harness populist anger at an economic system that has turned America into a feudalism. The book proved to be prescient — and I think we are once again at such a turning point, with a moment of opportunity.

We’re trying to do our part here at The Daily Poster to try to make sure that opportunity is seized — and we couldn’t do it without your support. The stakes are high: Whether or not we as a society seize this opportunity will determine the future of the country and the planet.
